intro: Alaida pectinata, commonly known as the pectinate alaida, is a species of flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of South America. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants commonly known as the buckwheat family. The plant is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, clustered flowers that bloom in late summer. Its leaves are alternate and have a distinctive pectinate (toothed) margin, giving it its scientific name. Alaida pectinata is often found in moist, rocky soils and is adapted to high-altitude environments.
